item.title: Quantization in deep learning architectures
item.description:
Introduction

Quantization, in the context of neural network is a lossy compression process of mapping float values of weights of either a pre-trained kernel or during a neural network training to a fixed bit-width representation. The mapping constraints the network to lose an affordable accuracy of the model’s performance, depending on the size of the chosen bit-width.

Generally, quantization compresses the network allowing to store the model more efficiently in the memory. In specialized hardwares (Accelerators) or SIMD supported CPUs, the stored weights are vectorized for the computation to increase the speed of the inference significantly.
item.content:
Introduction

Quantization, in the context of neural network is a lossy compression process of mapping float values of weights of either a pre-trained kernel or during a neural network training to a fixed bit-width representation. The mapping constraints the network to lose an affordable accuracy of the model’s performance, depending on the size of the chosen bit-width.

Generally, quantization compresses the network allowing to store the model more efficiently in the memory. In specialized hardwares (Accelerators) or SIMD supported CPUs, the stored weights are vectorized for the computation to increase the speed of the inference significantly.

Mathematically, we can say the mapping as:

$$ \left( \sum_{k=1}^n a_k b_k \right)^2 \leq \left( \sum_{k=1}^n a_k^2 \right) \left( \sum_{k=1}^n b_k^2 \right) $$

References

  1. Leo MAO’s Log Book - Quantization for Neural Networks
  2. Quantization and Training of Neural Networks for Efficient Integer-Arithmetic-Only Inference
